1.description: A young boy living temporarily with his aunt and uncle in London while his mother is ill. He befriends Polly Plummer, the girl next door.

2.description: Brave and determined to rescue Polly from Uncle Andrew's magic. He reluctantly agrees to wear the rings and venture into unknown worlds to save his friend.

5.description: Makes the fateful decision to ring the bell in Charn despite Polly's warnings, awakening the evil Queen Jadis. His curiosity and pride lead to bringing evil into both London and later Narnia.

10.description: Given a mission by Aslan to obtain a magical apple to protect Narnia from the evil he inadvertently brought into it. Shows maturity and responsibility in accepting this quest.

15.description: Grows up to become Professor Kirke, the same professor who will later house the Pevensie children. Uses the wood from the apple tree to make the famous wardrobe.

1.description: A practical and sensible girl who lives next door to Digory. She becomes his friend and partner in their adventures through different worlds.

2.description: The first victim of Uncle Andrew's magic rings, disappearing when she touches a yellow ring. Her disappearance forces Digory to follow her into the unknown.

5.description: Shows wisdom and caution in Charn, warning Digory not to ring the bell. Her sensible nature contrasts with Digory's impulsive curiosity.

9.description: Witnesses the creation of Narnia and is present when Aslan establishes the talking animals and chooses Frank to be the first King.

1.description: Digory's uncle who conducts mysterious experiments in his study. He is secretive and forbids anyone from entering his private room.

2.description: Revealed to be a magician who has created magic rings from dust that belonged to Jadis's world. He tricks Polly into touching a ring and forces Digory to rescue her.

7.description: Attempts to control and use Jadis for his own purposes, but she sees through his weakness immediately. His cowardice and selfishness are fully revealed.

14.description: Chastened by his experience in Narnia but quickly convinces himself it was all a dream. He abandons magic and becomes a reformed character.

1.description: Digory's aunt who takes care of him and his dying mother. She is kind but overwhelmed by the situation and often worried about practical matters.
Digory's beloved mother who is dying of an illness. Her condition is the source of Digory's greatest worry and motivation throughout his adventures.

14.description: Completely healed by the magical apple that Aslan gave to Digory. Her recovery brings joy and relief to Digory and the entire household.

5.description: The last Queen of Charn, awakened by Digory ringing the bell. She destroyed all life in her world, including her own sister, rather than surrender her throne. She is beautiful but terrible, with immense strength and cruelty.

6.description: Causes chaos in London, demonstrating her supernatural strength by breaking off pieces of a lamp-post and throwing a hansom cab. She treats the modern world with contempt.

7.description: Immediately sees through Uncle Andrew's weakness and attempts to manipulate him. She fights off the police and shows her complete lack of mercy or compassion.

12.description: Has eaten an apple from the Tree of Protection, gaining immortality but at the cost of misery. She tries to tempt Digory with lies about the apple's power, but he sees through her deception.

8.description: The great Lion who sings Narnia into existence. His voice creates the stars, sun, land, and all living things. He is the true ruler and creator of Narnia.

9.description: Gives the gift of speech to certain animals, making them the talking beasts of Narnia. He chooses Frank the cabby to be the first King of Narnia and brings Helen to be Queen.

10.description: Shows both justice and mercy to Digory, acknowledging that while Digory brought evil into Narnia, he will also be given a chance to help protect it through a quest.
10.role: Just judge and merciful giver of quests

13.description: Accepts Digory's successful completion of the quest and creates the Tree of Protection to guard Narnia. He gives Digory an apple to heal his dying mother.

8.description: Aslan's father, mentioned as the ultimate authority over all worlds. Though not seen directly, his power and authority are acknowledged by Aslan himself.

6.description: A London cab-driver whose horse Strawberry is frightened by Jadis. He is an honest, working-class man caught up in the magical chaos in the streets of London.

7.description: Caught up in the magical transport to other worlds when everyone grabs the rings. He maintains his practical, down-to-earth nature even in extraordinary circumstances.

9.description: Chosen by Aslan to be the first King of Narnia. His honest, kind nature and love for his wife Helen make him worthy of the crown. He accepts the responsibility with humility.
Frank's wife, brought from London by Aslan to be the first Queen of Narnia. She is a good-hearted woman who complements Frank's honest nature.

6.description: Frank's cab-horse who is frightened by Jadis's violent behavior in London. He is a tired old working horse who has spent his life pulling cabs through the city streets.

9.description: Given the gift of speech by Aslan and becomes one of the first talking animals of Narnia. He can now express his thoughts and feelings about his hard life in London.

11.description: Transformed by Aslan into a magnificent winged horse named Fledge. He carries Digory and Polly on their quest to the garden of the Tree of Protection.

5.description: The sister of Queen Jadis who fought her for the throne of Charn. Rather than let her sister rule, Jadis spoke the Deplorable Word and destroyed all life, including her sister.

7.description: London police officers who attempt to arrest Jadis for the chaos she's causing in the streets. They are no match for her supernatural strength and are easily fought off.

14.description: The housemaid at the Ketterley residence who witnesses the miraculous recovery of Digory's mother after eating the magical apple.

6.description: A gathering crowd of curious Londoners who witness Jadis's demonstration of supernatural strength. They are amazed and frightened by her ability to break lamp-posts and throw cabs.

1.description: Digory's father who is away in India on business, unable to return while his wife is dying. His absence adds to Digory's burden and loneliness.

15.description: Returns from India after his wife's miraculous recovery. He witnesses the happiness of his restored family and Digory's growth into maturity.

1.description: A nurse hired to care for Digory's dying mother. She provides professional medical care but can do little to prevent the inevitable decline.

14.description: Witnesses the miraculous healing of Mabel Kirke and is amazed by the sudden transformation from dying patient to healthy woman.

1.description: The cook working in the Ketterley household, responsible for preparing meals during the difficult time of Mabel's illness.

14.description: Celebrates the miraculous recovery of the mistress of the house. She helps prepare celebratory meals for the restored family.

2.description: Uncle Andrew's and Aunt Letty's father, mentioned as the source of Uncle Andrew's box containing magical dust from Atlantis. He had dealings with mysterious people and artifacts.
Uncle Andrew's fairy godmother who was imprisoned and gave him a box before she died. The box contained dust from Atlantis which Uncle Andrew used to make his magic rings.

4.description: The people of Charn who appear as lifelike statues in the great hall. They sit perfectly still, dressed in rich clothing, representing the former glory and nobility of the dead world.

5.description: Revealed to be truly dead, destroyed by Jadis speaking the Deplorable Word. They represent the countless innocent lives sacrificed for Jadis's pride and power.

4.description: The nobles and courtiers of Charn seen as statues in the hall. Their rich clothing and proud bearing suggest they were once powerful members of society.

9.description: The first animals to be given the gift of speech by Aslan. They include elephants, dogs, bears, and many other species who become the first council of Narnia.
One of the first animals to receive speech from Aslan. He becomes a leader among the talking animals and speaks with wisdom about their new responsibilities.
One of the talking birds created by Aslan. True to his nature, he is rather chatty and sometimes speaks out of turn during serious moments.
A loyal dog given speech by Aslan. He represents the faithful and brave nature of dogs, ready to serve the new kings and protect Narnia.

12.description: A beautiful tree in the garden on the mountain that bears silver apples with protective powers. The tree's apples can grant immortality but are meant to protect Narnia from evil.

13.description: Planted in Narnia by Digory under Aslan's direction. The tree will protect Narnia from Jadis for many years, as its presence is painful to her due to how she obtained immortality.

9.description: A wise talking raven given speech by Aslan. Ravens are traditionally associated with wisdom and prophecy, and this one serves as an advisor to the new kingdom.
A large bear given the gift of speech by Aslan. He represents strength and protection among the new talking animals of Narnia.
A hardworking donkey given speech by Aslan. He represents humility and honest labor among the talking animals.
A graceful leopard granted speech by Aslan. He represents speed and agility among the diverse council of talking animals.
A noble panther given the ability to speak by Aslan. Panthers are associated with nobility and stealth, making valuable additions to Narnia's council.
A quick rabbit granted speech by Aslan. Despite being small, he has an important voice in the council of talking animals.
A humble mole given speech by Aslan. He represents those who work beneath the surface and understand the earth itself.
A magnificent stag given speech by Aslan. He represents the wild, free spirit of the forest and serves as a messenger and scout.
A tiny but brave mouse granted speech by Aslan. Despite his small size, he has courage and determination that make him valuable to the talking animal council.
A cheerful robin given the gift of speech by Aslan. Robins are traditionally harbingers of good news and hope, making him a welcome voice in the council.
A wise owl granted speech by Aslan. Owls are traditionally associated with wisdom and night vision, making valuable contributions to the animal council.
Animals not chosen by Aslan to receive the gift of speech. They remain as ordinary animals and are to be cared for and protected by the talking animals.

relationships.Aslan: Created by but not given speech

8.description: A piece of the London lamp-post that Jadis broke off and threw. When it lands in the newly created Narnia, it takes root and grows into a proper lamp-post, becoming a landmark.

15.description: The same lamp-post that will later mark the entrance to Narnia for the Pevensie children. It stands as a reminder of how London and Narnia became connected through magic.

relationships.Digory Kirke: Connected to through the wardrobe he will make

6.description: A London cab driver whose hansom cab is picked up and thrown by Jadis as a demonstration of her strength. He is terrified by her supernatural abilities.
A well-dressed London gentleman who witnesses Jadis's rampage in the street. He represents the upper-class Victorian society shocked by the supernatural events.

7.description: A London policeman attempting to arrest Jadis. His helmet is knocked off during the scuffle, showing how outmatched the authorities are against her power.

6.description: A working-class boy on the London streets who witnesses Jadis's display of strength. He represents the common people amazed by the magical chaos.
A London shopkeeper who comes out of his store to see what the commotion is about. He watches in amazement as Jadis demonstrates her supernatural powers.
A London housewife who joins the growing crowd to witness Jadis's rampage. She represents the domestic sphere disrupted by magical events.
A London newspaper vendor who abandons his papers to watch Jadis's demonstration of power. His amazement shows how the supernatural has interrupted normal commerce.
A London omnibus driver who stops his vehicle to watch the chaos caused by Jadis. His horses become nervous from the supernatural disturbance.

7.description: A senior police officer who leads the attempt to arrest Jadis. Despite his authority and experience, he is no match for her supernatural strength.

1.description: The physician treating Digory's dying mother. He provides little hope for her recovery, making Digory's quest for a cure all the more urgent.

14.description: Amazed by the miraculous recovery of Mabel Kirke after she eats the magical apple. He cannot explain the sudden cure medically.

3.description: Massive, ancient trees that fill the Wood Between the Worlds. They are incredibly old and seem to have a peaceful, sleepy quality that affects all visitors.

2.description: Uncle Andrew's guinea pig used to test his magic rings. The poor animal is sent to other worlds as an experiment before Uncle Andrew dares to use the rings on humans.

3.description: Found by the children in the Wood Between the Worlds, having been sent there by Uncle Andrew's ring. The guinea pig shows signs of having been in the peaceful wood for some time.
Countless pools scattered throughout the Wood Between the Worlds, each leading to a different world. They appear as clear, still water that reflects the sky above.

2.description: Magic rings made by Uncle Andrew from Atlantis dust. They transport the wearer from their current world to the Wood Between the Worlds.
Magic rings made by Uncle Andrew from Atlantis dust. They transport the wearer from the Wood Between the Worlds back to their home world.

4.description: Armored guards who once protected the royal palace of Charn. They appear as stone-still figures in their armor, eternally frozen at their posts.

5.description: A massive golden bell with a hammer beside it, inscribed with a verse warning of consequences. When struck by Digory, it awakens Jadis from her enchanted sleep.
A terrible word of magic known only to Jadis that destroyed all living things in Charn. It represents the ultimate expression of selfish power and destruction.

4.description: The magnificent throne where Jadis once ruled as Queen of Charn. It sits empty in the great hall, a symbol of power that ultimately led to destruction.

2.description: Magical dust from the lost world of Atlantis, contained in Mrs. Lefay's box. Uncle Andrew uses this dust to create the yellow and green rings that transport people between worlds.

4.description: The vast, empty palace of Charn filled with halls of frozen statues. Once a center of power and luxury, now a monument to the consequences of absolute authority.

12.description: Beautiful birds that sing in the garden where the Tree of Protection grows. Their songs add to the magical beauty and peace of the sacred mountain garden.

9.description: A lively squirrel given speech by Aslan. True to squirrel nature, he is energetic and quick-moving, bringing energy to the council of talking animals.
A fox granted speech by Aslan, bringing natural cunning and intelligence to the council. Foxes are known for their cleverness and adaptability.
A badger granted speech by Aslan who becomes known for his wisdom and practical advice. Badgers are traditionally associated with persistence and earth wisdom.
A sure-footed goat granted speech by Aslan. Goats are known for their ability to navigate difficult terrain, making them valuable scouts and messengers.
A woolly sheep given speech by Aslan. Sheep represent gentleness and community, bringing peaceful wisdom to the council of talking animals.
A beaver given speech by Aslan who will help build and maintain the infrastructure of the new kingdom. Beavers are natural builders and engineers.
A playful otter given speech by Aslan who brings joy and water knowledge to the council. Otters are known for their playfulness and swimming ability.
A humble mole given speech by Aslan. He represents those who work beneath the surface and understand the earth itself, bringing underground wisdom.
A quick weasel granted speech by Aslan. Weasels are known for their speed and agility, making them excellent scouts and messengers.

15.description: The wardrobe that Professor Kirke will have made from the wood of the magical apple tree. This wardrobe will later become the portal through which the Pevensie children enter Narnia.

14.description: The tree that grows from the apple core Digory plants in his London garden. It carries the magic from Narnia and will eventually be used to make the famous wardrobe.

15.description: When the tree is blown down in a storm, its wood is used to make the wardrobe that will later transport the Pevensie children to Narnia, completing the magical circle.
The storm that eventually blows down the apple tree grown from the Narnian apple core, allowing its wood to be used for the famous wardrobe.

recaps.1: Young Digory Kirke is staying with his Aunt Letty and Uncle Andrew in London while his mother is dying. He meets Polly Plummer, who lives next door, and they become friends. Uncle Andrew is revealed to be conducting mysterious experiments in his study.
recaps.2: Polly and Digory discover they can travel between the attics of their row houses. When Polly accidentally enters Uncle Andrew's forbidden study, he tricks her into touching a yellow ring that makes her disappear. Uncle Andrew reveals he is a magician and forces Digory to rescue Polly using the rings.
recaps.3: Digory puts on the yellow ring and finds himself in the Wood Between the Worlds, a peaceful forest with pools that lead to different worlds. He finds Polly and they discover that green rings bring them back to the wood, while yellow rings take them to other worlds.
recaps.4: The children jump into a pool and arrive in the dying world of Charn, filled with ruined palaces and silent, empty cities. In the great hall, they find rows of richly dressed people sitting perfectly still, as if turned to stone.
recaps.5: Despite Polly's warnings, Digory strikes a golden bell with a hammer, awakening Jadis, the last Queen of Charn. She tells them how she destroyed all life in her world, including her sister, rather than lose her throne. Jadis follows them back to London when they try to escape.
recaps.6: Jadis wreaks havoc in London, demonstrating her terrible strength by breaking off pieces of a lamp-post and throwing a hansom cab. A crowd gathers, including Frank the cab-driver, as Jadis demands to be taken to their world's ruler.
recaps.7: Uncle Andrew tries to control Jadis but she sees through his weakness immediately. The police attempt to arrest her, but she fights them off. In the chaos, everyone grabs the children's rings and are transported together to the Wood Between the Worlds.
recaps.8: The group arrives in a world of complete darkness and nothing. Suddenly, Aslan appears and begins singing the world of Narnia into existence, creating stars, sun, landscape, and finally plants and animals with his voice.
recaps.9: Aslan continues creating Narnia, calling forth talking animals and establishing them as the rulers of the new world. Frank the cab-driver is chosen to be the first King of Narnia, and his wife Helen is brought from London to be Queen.
recaps.10: Aslan speaks privately with Digory about the evil he has brought into Narnia by awakening Jadis. He gives Digory a chance to help protect Narnia by undertaking a dangerous quest to obtain a magical apple.
recaps.11: Aslan transforms Frank's horse Strawberry into the winged horse Fledge. Digory and Polly fly on Fledge to a beautiful garden on a high mountain, passing over the newly created wonders of Narnia.
recaps.12: In the garden, Digory finds the Tree of Protection with its silver apples. He is tempted by Jadis, who has already eaten an apple and gained immortality, but he resists her lies and takes only one apple as Aslan commanded.
recaps.13: Digory returns to Aslan and plants the apple, which immediately grows into a great tree that will protect Narnia from Jadis for many years. Aslan gives Digory an apple from this tree to heal his dying mother.
recaps.14: The group returns to London, where Digory's apple completely heals his mother. Uncle Andrew is chastened by his experience but quickly convinces himself it was all a dream. Digory plants the apple core in his backyard.
recaps.15: Years later, the apple core has grown into a tree. When a storm brings it down, Digory has its wood made into a wardrobe - the same wardrobe through which the Pevensie children will later enter Narnia. Digory grows up to become Professor Kirke.
